etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in Thomas Harman (fl. 1547–1567), writer on vagabonds. Probably an alteration of classical Latin pānem, accusative of pānis bread, probably arising from its occurrence in the verse from the Lord's prayer, post-classical Latin panem nostrum da nobis hodie ‘give us this day our daily bread’

definitions: In full "pannam stall". A fairground stall selling confectionery.
